newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks end slightly up as techs, bonds surge.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks end slightly up as techs, bonds surge.

text.p: U.S. stocks ended modestly higher, bolstered by a rally in bonds and high-technology issues, as traders repriced stocks a day after the Fed surprised some by leaving interest rates unchanged.

"Technology is doing well and bonds are doing very well. But there's still some caution. People are not rushing head-long into the market," said Hildegard Zagorski, a market analyst at Prudential Securities.
The Dow rose three to about 5877 after Tuesday gyrating to a 21-point loss on news of no change in U.S. monetary policy.
Winners beat losers 6-5 on very heavy NYSE volume of about 448 million shares.

The tech-studded Nasdaq Composite surged nine to about 1225. Technology buying was stoked by 3Com Corp's unexpectedly strong first-quarter earnings report. Shares in the computer networking company rallied eight to 64-5/8.
The long bond climbed 22/32 to yield 6.93 percent, decisively below the key seven percent level, after strong demand for Treasury's $18.25 billion auction of two-year notes.
Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany, said the market's focus was "earnings, earnings, earnings."

"Defensive industry groups are performing better than economically sensitive, aside from technology. On the plus side we have banks, food stocks and household products -- those whose earnings tend to do well if the economy slows. On the negative side, autos and retailers," he said.
Citicorp edged up 1/8 to 89-7/8, Sara Lee added 7/8 to 34-3/4, GM lost 7/8 to 47-1/2 and Sears fell 1/4 to 45-1/2.
"Compare the performance of 3Com or Cisco with Apple South and Checkpoint Systems," Johnson said.
Apple South slumped 7-7/8 to 13 and Checkpoint tumbled nine to 27-3/8 after they warned of earnings shortfalls.
"There is a deep concern that earnings are going to slow and you need to pick the stocks of companies that will continue to post good earnings," Johnson added.

Among other stocks, Loral Space rose 2-1/2 to 15-3/4 after agreeing to buy AT&T's SkyNet Satellite Services for $712.5 million in cash, in a deal that would create the world's largest satellite-based businesses. AT&T rose 1/4 to 51-3/4 after Tuesday's 5-5/8-point drubbing on an earnings warning.
Apria Healthcare lost 3-3/8 to 17-3/8 after forecasting it would report third-quarter net income that would fall short of Wall Street expectations.
Several initial public offerings drew buying interest. Snyder Communications, which provides outsourced marketing services, surged 3-5/8 to 20-5/8.

American Residential Services, a provider of heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems service, rose three to 18 and Coffee People lost 3/4 to 8-1/4. Among others making Wall Street debuts, LCC International, which provides radio frequency engineering and network design services for the wireless telecommunications industry, climbed four to 20.
Amway Asia Pacific rose 4-1/8 to 33-7/8. Merrill Lynch named Amway its Focus One stock of the week.

TCSI Corp, a maker of communications software mainly for telephone companies, lost 5-1/4 to 15-1/2 on market talk the company would not meet third-quarter earnings expectations. Company officials were not available for comment.

Biotechs rallied from a summer slump after some positive industry news. Protein Design jumped 9-7/8 to 26 after it and Roche Holding said their Zenepax drug was successful for preventing kidney transplant rejection in a late-stage trial.
Genetics Institute rose 1-1/4 to 65-7/8 after signing Chiron and Genentech as partners for a protein discovery program.
Biotech group bellwether Amgen rose 1-1/2 to 63-3/8.
Among stronger technology stocks, IBM added 2-3/8 to 126-1/2, Micron rose 1-1/8 to 32-1/2, Cisco Systems was up 2-11/16 to 63-3/16 and Intel added 3/4 to 97-1/4.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 9.39 to 1224.66.
The S&P 500 index rose 0.22 to 685.83.
(Figures official as of 1645 EDT/2045 GMT)
-- Wall Street desk, 212 859 1721
